comments.commentBody:
Susan,
The email goes on because we keep getting more and more drips and slips. A lie this big is hard to keep shushed. Too many people involved. Including those that may have hacked her server. Cause despite your research talking point, Comey stated that they wouldn't fine evidence if they had. He also found it likely more than not because of the locations she sent and received from. What does any of these released emails have to do with your assertion of "personal" deletions?
Also, just because a opposition adversary digs the dirt, doesn't make it any less true. Thus you need to stop with the assertions that all criticism is Reichwing. Cause lord knows the left couldn't find their own. Right Susan? The truth is what it is, whether it comes from a left or right. Obviously the left has done a poor job of vetting Slick Hilliey. She was crammed down our throats from the get go. Imagine people being upset about that. Hmmm...
Here is a "fact check" giving HRC 3 Pinocchio's for her lies and deception on the emails from the beginning. https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2016/07/05/revisitin...

Here's the problem. (aside from the unnecessary dig "Reichwing")

It's the double standard. People come in a wide variety, which is great. But attacks on Hillary are out of proportion to what she did, and one side is eager to fan the flames. Since Judicial Watch has still not been properly exposed, and Republican opposition work is so deep and wide, the picture is distorted. Republicans never admit weakness or break ranks.

I often refer to climate because that's where I'm bruised and battered. When one side never lets up and uses every trick in the book, it's hard to say, yes, people are flawed, but that's who we are, and that can be a good thing.

On the whole, Hillary, a busy woman, appears to have done what she could in complicated circumstances, and I'm inclined to think the whole email attack thing is overblown and driven from the right.

Unfortunately, none of this leaves room for me to say, yes, I want universal health care (good luck with that), yes, I want to redo military history and stop ruining other people's neighborhoods in the name of being the world's policeman, yes, I want to go back to Eisenhower-level taxation (look it up, it's staggering), yes, social security and sales taxes are regressive, yes, the Clinton and Obama shouldn't have caved (as if they had a choice) after we didn't support them in midterms, yada yada yada.

I voted for Bernie, but in the end I got tired of his lack of a plan and over a decade of uncompromising repetition.

Susan,
Thank you for your courteous reply. Well done.
Seems we could agree on many things. Others not so much.
Such is life.
Thus, not all criticism is/are rightwing points.
You seem to be willing to give a pass to Ms. Clinton on her emails. I, not so much. Show me the "personal", then maybe I'd hire her.
As for Bernie, one must start out with the "Big Ideas". One has a cabinet and negotiations to try and make it happen. If one starts out compromised, as BHO always seemed to do, as Dem. politicians always seem to do, as HRC sounds/seems willing already to do, then half the win is already in the oppositions court. Yes, politics is a give and take. Why do we always seem to give from the start? I prefer Sanders style. We do know that the Amendment King knows how to bargain. And he gets his ideas implemented as best as he could. Especially when even his so called Dem. caucus wouldn't sit and listen, much less work for his "unicorn'' ideas.
Better than nothing, sometimes is not good enough. Kinda like Climate Change. We do or we don't and perish. Should we compromise on this to our detriment when we know we are right?
Such is life. Good luck with your choice. We will all need it.

Ukrainian "Anti-Corruption Officials"--like Comey's FBI agents--"where government investigators examining secret records have found his name" but not sure he received cash? And "hand-written ledgers", no less--though without his name--, right, like DNC's emails and Hillary's lawyers-wiped and deleted 30,000 emails?

Looking for the "Bill gets $500K from the Kremlin entry and Hillary extorts many millions from the Saudis as Obama's Secretary of State" ledger--to show how she and Bill mixed money and politics. Don't know how much her State Department fellows made off with, though. FBI looking for a "hand-written" ledger?

Fascinating election--winner with the least corruption in past and thinnest FBI folder takes the White House from current Mr. Executive-Order President?

Yeah, America the brave and beautiful. So it goes in the post-modern period of American politics.
Manafort could be a Russian mole? Or is? FBI, forget HRC's wedding planning emails & investigate CrookedTrump and Criminal Manafirt ... now!

One wonders if Trump would conceivably share the nuclear codes with his pal Putin... his own interpretation of detente.  "Hey, no big deal," right?  "Putin and I understand each other."  Aren't those recent Trump quotes?  Or maybe that was just more theater for the media? Meanwhile, Trump supporters at his rallies continue to excoriate Obama as a socialist bent on selling out and destroying America.  Oh, the irony.
If only we had never pushed Yanukovych out of Ukraine. Big Obama mistake.
And another: criminal
Could Putin have made an offer to Trump he couldn't refuse? Hire Manafort to work on the Trump campaign as a condition of the loan we gave you?
Worse - probably his chief of staff, his consigliere.

NYT gave him a forum to expose himself as a mediocre thinker who obviously has a low opinion of readers' (the electorate's) intelligence. IMO he sounds like a self-serving idiot and I'm pleased to see it displayed.
The application of even a smidge of logic takes his argument apart. Thanks, NYT, for exposing him via his own words.

@MEM
They are “acquiescing” to Captain Combover’s 100 tweets over the last four days about the dishonest media’s negative reporting...s/

Oh BTW--Trump has a special plea on his website. He’s calling for his disciples to volunteer and pledge as “poll watchers” especially in “certain neighborhoods” in Pennsylvania.

Yes! You too can sign onto Trump’s militia to make sure folks aren’t voting 10 times for someone else! (He said “Its’ okay to vote for ME 10 times.”) This new legion of Trumpites must break EVERY rule for established polling stations’ written conduct policies established in every state!

to MEM:   Why should Mr. Sanford's "personal history of lies and scandal" keep the Press from giving him a forum - Trump's personal history of lies and scandal haven't prevented the Press from giving Trump an endless forum!  Sanford is a lightweight in the personal history of lies and scandal when compared to Trump!
I am disappointed that the NY Times gave a forum to Mr. Stanford to discuss political ethics, given his personal history of lies and scandal.
Endorsing Trump without seeing his tax returns is something only a sucker born yesterday would do.

Thank you Ms. Scott.  I have always wondered why people keep blaming Obama for the country's economic "stagnation."  Obama lost the House two years after taking office.  Even before then, Republicans met secretly to oppose almost every piece of meaningful legislation he sent to Congress, even if it meant hurting the country - and they talked about patriotism!  I keep hearing reporters say over 2/3 of Americans believe the country is going in the wrong direction, yet Obama is quite popular.  Has any one stopped to think the wrong direction could be faulted to Republicans?  I also agreed with you that what they could not block in the Congress they used Republican Justices on the Supreme Court to override.  It was these justices as you mentioned, who Deprived many Americans the right to vote and their Citizens United have severely undermined American democracy which likely contributed to the rise of Trump.  But given he is who Republicans have now selected to be President, one can be charitable to Rep. Sanford.  At least he offered a valid argument and he did not overtly insult all Americans and belittle the country even though many of us can be offended by his behavior while he was Governor.

Mary—an excellent description of our present twisted system.  You are absolutely correct.  The legislative branch is on permanent vacation, resting at happy hours everywhere, and the stacked court rules like a junta. Incisive insight.  Thanks.

Donald Trump needs to produce his tax returns for all the reasons Representative Sanford gave. It is the right thing to do, an accepted protocol all presidential candidates have dutifully concurred with for fifty years.

As far as the Supreme Court is concerned, Republicans have abused the majority they've held for over fifty years because they've used their court majority to push their agenda forward rather than legislating.

In the past six years, in all three congressional sessions, the Republican controlled House has been the least productive since we've been keeping track. When Senate Republicans gained the majority in 2014 they followed the House in failing to legislate. Prior to that, they abused the filibuster to block legislation more than any other party in the history of our country. Rather than make laws, they sue or a conservative group sues for them. Then, the conservative majority usually finds for them.

That's how we got "Citizens United" and the decimation of the Voting Rights Act. It's why business seems always the victor over labor. It's why so many Americans are disgusted with Congress. Republican obstruction is the primary cause of Congressional Gridlock.

It's time for a Democratic Supreme Court majority. Let's do it in November by electing Hillary Clinton and let's end Congressional Gridlock by electing a Democratic Congress that will actually start legislating again and restore honor to the legislative branch of government.
So, Mark, since all know that's not going to happen, who's your choice with the codes?
The only one I don't trust is the Trumpeter who has blatantly announced will use nuclear weapons. Enough said.

A great fear in the coming election is that the new President will make a nuclear strike.

Hillary's supporters say Trump is unstable, does not recognize the importance of such talk, and could easily end up using them. It is part of the "crazy Trump" strategy.

The other side has heard Hillary threaten first use, and believes she is a hawk to such an extreme that she just might.

Both parties therefore have reason to agree to make structural changes now to prevent the candidate they fear from reckless use of nuclear weapons.

Obama could propose a change in the command system, to make clear that the President does not have that authority, the "Football" does not work for first use. Both parties could and should agree to that change.

Never mind protesting that your candidate never would. Both believe the other guy's candidate would. That is enough.

For the record, I don't trust either one, but that isn't decisive, the wide agreement that the other guy is dangerous ought to be enough.
I heard someplace that it was eight other children with six other women.
What's the problem, Susan? A guy has to earn a living, the good old American way.
Putin and Le Pen have at least one thing in common, and that is rabid nationalism.
Politics is incestuous. Dig deeper and you will find "both" republicans and democrats entangled with a messy world.

Putin has been busy cultivating disaffection in Europe as well. Interestingly, Marine le Pen, the far right candidate in France, said she'd cooperate. This kind of thing is normal for Russia. People who think the cold war is over should look again. WaPo has an analysis of Putin's efforts here that covers some of the European shenanigans:
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/alleged-russian-involvement-...

Oh, this is rich. Along with almost every Republican, Manafort has quite a collection of dictators in his portfolio (source: wikipedia):

"Manafort was an adviser to the presidential campaigns of Republicans Gerald Ford, Ronald Reagan, George H. W. Bush, Bob Dole ... successful lobbying efforts on behalf of political leaders like Jonas Savimbi and Viktor Yanukovych and foreign dictators such as Ferdinand Marcos and Mobutu Sese Seko."

Cindy, Hillary won't tell us what she said in a speech given on American soil to an American bank.
Why the secrecy? No one has to establish equivalency to find Hillary's stonewalling remarkable.
Remember, she wants our votes, and therefore our trust - is she earning that trust?
It seems she can't even be trusted to quote Comey correctly - he did not say she was "truthful." She even lies about this! Remarkable.

@Mark
The Repubs will start hearings soon; don't fret.

You definitely do not exhibit that you have any workable knowledge of the GOP issues with Russia that has been at the heart of Republican politics for nearly a century. I would have to say you seem to  know nothing about the Cold War from your posts. Unreal.

An aide ought not to take such serious money from powerful interests.

Neither should a candidate herself, but one did, even more money than involved here, and what she said in return is kept secret.

If Ukraine keptocrats are serious interests, then so is Wall Street and major corporations.

So yes, this is right. Apply it to both sides.

Hillary's lawyers deleted emails that were "personal". It's not quite the same thing.

Meanwhile, Judicial Watch, who is spearheading the email attacks, is a right-leaning organization that has persecuted the Clintons and Obama and recently joined with Rep. Lamar Smith in attacking climate science, scientists, and NOAA. They want to claim the changing climate is a political, but has anybody noticed Louisiana lately? Other stuff that is getting off the charts?

This is a case where certainty is impossible. Leaving interest rates where they are would be doing nothing. But since the Feds have the option every month to change rates, even inaction is a form of action.  So, technically, if not meaningfully, Krugman's counsel is for inaction in the face of doubt. But, actually, there is no way to for the Fed not to have an effect on the economy whether it stands pat or raises rates. So they're stuck with doubt no matter what they do. This is a case of which is the lesser of 2 possible evils.

In his article today, Paul writes:

"But whatever doubts they may be feeling don’t excuse their actions, and in fact make them even less forgivable"

The stifling of doubt, as William Clifford showed in his famous essay of 1877, "The Ethics of Belief", is a major moral shortcoming. Believing and/or acting on the basis of insufficient evidence is obviously a serious matter - especially when we're talking about public policy.
It's true, RB.  Various people mean that question differently.

Spelling Bee backwards. Take the letters A and E, G, I, N, R and T. Go only for words using all 7 letters. I have 35, plus or minus a few questionables. Can you do better? Can you come up with 7 other letters giving even more 3-point words?

Agreed.  I found it absurd but necessary to censor myself almost all the time, depending on to whom I was talking (or typing).  We told no one except a very few very close friends until we knew for sure what my diagnosis was and what the treatment plan would be.  And even then it was not common knowledge until I was well into my treatment.  There was nothing most people could do except offer verbal support (not even food, as I was unable to eat throughout my treatment and for the better part of a year afterward--who knows what my daughter and husband survived on;  I certainly don't).

@Socrates
“to hikers like yourself”

Oh well done! Just a slip of the dagger blade between the ribs of the Appalachian Trail Luv Guv!
He has no decency.  Also I really do not think there is a Conservative party left.  It is gone with the wind. Trump proposed party has none of the old conservative values in it.

@Susan H
Two ex-WIVES not just “ex-wife.”

And when he was openly cheating on wife #1, the NY tabloids actually had a full page quote from Trump’s cheating partner Marla Maples”
“Best Sex I Ever Had!”

Whatta guy!

"I am a conservative Republican who...intends to support my party’s nominee because of the importance of filling the existing vacancy on the Supreme Court, and others that might in the next four years."

That's right, Representative Sanford, the fact that Donald Trump is a demonstrated national security risk, pays zero income taxes and appears to be mentally unbalanced is apparently unimportant to 'conservative Republicans'.

What's really important to hikers like yourself is to have the Supreme Court properly staffed with right-wing retainers in case the Supreme Court needs to tell the nation's voters to 'take a giant hike' like they did in November 2000.

South Carolina, still proudly waving that Good Old Boy Confederate flag of patriotic sedition and intellectual bankruptcy with Congressman Sanford.

Party First and Country Last...with hot biscuits and gravy.

Have you no decency, Congressman ?

I am involved in several online cancer support groups and I always counsel the newly-diagnosed to take people up on their offers of help.  Honestly it can be almost impossible to figure out who actually wants to help and who doesn't, and I haven't found that the manner of offering correlates with the willingness to help.  A few people kindly offered specific help, and I was able to explain why I did or did not need that kind of help.  But I say to call on others to do things that need done.  Yes, some will let you down, but others, and often people who you didn't think would even care much, will come to your aid brilliantly.

Garnet--many cases of my cancer, head and neck, can not just be cured (although the cure rate is high, the treatment is brutal), but in many cases prevented.  All that is needed is a series of HPV vaccinations at or before puberty (before sexual activity).  It will prevent many cases of cervical and head and neck cancers, as well as others.  These cancers affect both men and women, and increasingly middle aged and younger men as well as women.

This is a case where certainty is impossible. Leaving interest rates where they are would be doing nothing. But since the Feds have the option every month to change rates, even inaction is a form of action.  So, technically, if not meaningfully, Krugman's counsel is for inaction in the face of doubt. But, actually, there is no way to for the Fed not to have an effect on the economy whether it stands pat or raises rates. So they're stuck with doubt no matter what they do. This is a case of which is the lesser of 2 possible evils.

Immunotherapy drugs, one of which, Keytruda, has just been approved for my cancer, head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, threaten to become true life savers.  Witness Jimmy Carter, a nonagenarian, whose melanoma lesions, including mets to his brain, have melted away so completely that he has stopped taking it and is out and about.  It only works in a minority of cases, but the averages do not show the dramatic effects on the population for whom it is effective.  We need more research in this direction, and more drugs that help more people.

Wow.  I have heard of such a thing.   I guess you have a good dose of equanimity?   Really I haven't met anyone who just had one medication-induced panic attack of "worry"  and nothing more emotionally that that.   Good for you.  I hope your recovery and equanimity continues.

I have recently been cured of throat cancer (head and neck squamous cell carcinoma) and thankfully have not had to endure any of the comments others have heard. In my case everyone seems surprised at how well I'm doing. But we did approach it somewhat differently than some. We told almost no one until I had a firm diagnosis and treatment plan. And even then we didn't tell a lot of people, but we got a lot of support from the ones who knew.

I was never angry, although I had the advantage of a pretty good prognosis if I could survive the treatment. And surviving the treatment is easier given a good prognosis, so that was a big help. I did have an episode of worry, but it turned out to be a panic attack caused by a medication imbalance. I sometimes wonder whether my attitude during my brutal radiation treatment was kind of pathological, as I didn't go through the stages of grief or "why me?" (Why not me? I figure it's all a crap shoot, and I lost, temporarily.)

I also had the advantage of not having watched commercial TV for decades, so those terrible ads never penetrated my consciousness.
